jsx
Class Source

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.Configurable
          jsx.Source
Direct Known Subclasses:
Ajax, Widget
public abstract class Source
extends Configurable

An abstract base class for event sources that fire high level events.

This class provides a simple but efficient high level event model. An event is an object of the Source.Event class. An event source is an object of the Source class. An event can be executed immediately from an event source with a call to the exec(Event) method. It can also be raised from a source for general dispatching with a call to the fire(Event) method, or for a specific dispatcher with a call to the fire(Event, TaskManager) method. An event dispatcher is actually a task manager of the TaskManager class. A fired event is, after converted to an event task, submitted to the task manager for scheduling to get handled by the listeners registered with the type of the events.

An event listener together with the type of events it handles must be registered with an event source object for an event task manager to dispatch events of the type to the listener for handling when the source object fires the events of that type. With one event type, an arbitrary number of listeners can be registered. The listeners registered to an event source with the same event type handle a dispatched event in the order registration.

Note that, event sources are Configurable.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org

Constructor Detail

Source

protected Source(ObjectLike ini)

A typical constructor forcing constructors of subclasses to pass initializing data.

This constructor simply invokes the typical constructor of the superclass passing a copy of the specified initializing object, or if the argument one is undefined, a newly created ObjectLike object as the argument.

Parameters:
ini - The initializing object that can also be created with an object literal.
Since:
1.0

                                                  java.lang.Class<? extends Source.Event<T>> et)

Parameters:

et - The event type to get listeners of.
Returns:

addListener

public final <T> void addListener(java.lang.Class<? extends Source.Event<T>> et,
                                  T on)

Registers an event listener, together with the event type it is allowed to handle, to this event source.

Note that, this method is not declared final so that subclasses can override it to provide more flexible wrapping support.

Parameters:
et - The event type this source allows the listener to handle.
on - The event listener this source allows to handle the type of event.
Since:
1.0

removeListeners

public final <T> void removeListeners(java.lang.Class<? extends Source.Event<T>> et)

Stops firing a certain type of events from this event source.

Note that, this method is not declared final so that subclasses can override it to provide more flexible wrapping support.

Parameters:
et - The type of events this source fires, which is to be disabled.
Since:
1.0

unwrap

protected abstract Source unwrap()

Returns the wrapped source object if this one is a wrapper source.

The high level event model supports the wrapping technology widely used in this library. The wrapped object of an event source must also be an event source. The event queuing and dispatching mechanism in this class tries to dispatch an event fired from an event source also to its wrapped source by calling this method, if this source does wrap another valid source.

A concrete method overriding this one in a subclass may return null for it does not wrap, the wrapped source object if it wraps one, or the current instance itself if it is a wrapped source but does not wrap others.

Returns:
The wrapped source object.
Since:
1.0

getParent

protected abstract Source getParent()

Returns the parent source object graphically containing the current one.

The wrapped object of an event source must also be an event source. The event queuing and dispatching mechanism of this class tries to dispatch an event fired from an event source also to its containing source by calling this method, if this source is graphically contained by another valid source and the event wants to bubble, that is, its Source.Event.BUBBLE configurable property is true.

A concrete method overriding this one in a subclass may return null when it is neither graphical nor contained, or the parent source object if it has one.

Returns:
The source object graphically containing this source object.
Since:
1.0

exec

public final <T> int exec(Source.Event<T> evt)

Executes an event from the current source object immediately if the source object fires that type of events.

An event becomes fired when it is successfully executed with this method.

The method does nothing if the event has been fired, or the event source does not fire that type of events, that is, the source does not have any listeners registered to it for the type of the event.

Note that, the caller of this method will not return until the event task has been finished running, and in JS Simulation mode the event is run in the same thread as the caller of this method does.

Parameters:
evt - The event to execute.
Returns:
The count of listeners which are executed successfully from the event source. The method returns 0 if the event has been fired, or if the event source does not fire that type of events, that is, the source does not have any listeners registered to it with the type of the event.
Since:
1.0

fire

public final <T> void fire(Source.Event<T> evt)

Raises the specified event from the current event source, to be queued for general event dispatching.

The method does nothing if the event has been fired, or the event source does not fire that type of events, that is, the source does not have any listeners registered to it for the type of the event.

An event dispatcher is actually a task manager. The fired event is, after converted to an event task, submitted to the task manager for dispatching.

The general event dispatcher processes events globally in default. Submitting events to the general event dispatcher makes sure all events are dispatched in the sequence that they are fired. Unless you know exactly what would be happening, use fire(Event) instead of fire(Event, TaskManager).

Note that, the caller of this method will return immediately after raising the event without having to wait for the event task to run, and in JS Simulation mode the event can be run in a different thread than the caller of this method does.

Parameters:
evt - The event being fired from this source.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
fire(Event, TaskManager), exec(Event)

fire

public final <T> void fire(Source.Event<T> evt,
                           TaskManager dispatcher)

Raises the specified event from the current event source, to be queued for specific event dispatching.

The method does nothing if the event has been fired or the event source does not fire that type of events, that is, the source does not have any listeners registered with the type of the event.

An event dispatcher is actually a task manager. The fired event is, after converted to an event task, submitted to the task manager for dispatching.

The general event dispatcher processes events globally in default. Submitting events to the general event dispatcher makes sure all events are dispatched in the sequence that they are fired. Unless you know exactly what would be happening, use fire(Event) instead of fire(Event, TaskManager).

Note that, the caller of this method will return immediately after raising the event without having to wait for the event task to run, and in JS Simulation mode the event can be run in a different thread as the caller of this method does.

Parameters:
evt - The event being fired from this source.
dispatcher - The event dispatcher to dispatch the fired event.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
fire(Event), exec(Event)
